Traditional research and development of catalysts mainly rely on experimental trial-and-error methods, which struggle to meet the demand for efficient catalysts in the energy and environmental fields. Applying machine learning to catalyst design can achieve rapid screening of catalysts, thus overcoming the limitations of the traditional trial-and-error methods and solving the problems of low efficiency and high cost affecting catalyst research and development. This paper reports the development of a catalytic database containing 751 sets of data, with 30 input features divided into three categories, such as catalyst composition, preparation conditions, and catalytic reaction conditions, along with NO x conversion and N2 selectivity serving as output features. A machine learning approach was used to assist in the formulation screening and performance prediction of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalysts. The Categorical boosting (CatBoost) model was found to exhibit the best performance among the 10 models explored, with R 2, Mean absolute error (MAE), and Root mean square error (RMSE) values of 0.999, 0.006, and 0.008, respectively. The importance of each input feature for model prediction was obtained using the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) method, which showed that the reaction temperature and Mn elemental molar ratio had the greatest effect on NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. This study provides guidance for the screening, reaction condition optimization, and performance prediction of SCR catalysts. The successful integration of machine learning with experimental methods represents an effective strategy that can accelerate the discovery of catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Machine learning SCR catalyst Precise screening Performance prediction N2 selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. However, fossil fuel combustion still dominates the energy mix of the country [1,2]. Nitrogen oxides (NO x ), as one of the major air pollutants produced by the combustion of fossil fuels, cause environmental issues such as haze, acid rain, and photochemical smog pollution [3]. The ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) technology is currently one of the most effective methods for terminal denitrification in coal-fired power plants, owing to its high efficiency, low reaction temperature, and absence of secondary pollution [4,5]. Catalysts play a central role in the NH3-SCR process, directly affecting the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity [6]. Currently, commercial SCR catalysts mainly include metal oxides based on vanadium (V), tungsten (W), and titanium (Ti), with high NO x conversion and N2 selectivity within a narrow active window of 300–400 °C. As the new power systems increasingly rely on renewable energy integration, coal-fired units must now operate with rapid and flexible peaking responses across wide load ranges to balance grid fluctuations. This demand for enhanced operational flexibility requires the development of novel SCR catalysts capable of maintaining high activity, long lifespan, and superior performance under variable load conditions, which makes their advancement a critical technical challenge [7]. Traditional catalyst development is mainly based on empirical approaches and iterative trial-and-error methods [8], which requires extensive testing and performance evaluation for each candidate formulation [9]. The emergence of “catalytic informatics” has caused a paradigm shift in multiphase catalysis research since 2001 [10]. This data-driven approach leverages large-scale reaction and compositional datasets to extract structure–activity relationships, identify performance-determining factors, and predict the behavior of catalysts. By integrating data mining and machine learning techniques, catalytic informatics enables rational design of catalysts and optimizes experimental workflows [11]. The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence has enabled widespread machine learning applications across diverse fields, including medicine [12], environment [13], energy [14], and finance [15]. By training on suitable datasets, machine learning builds predictive models that autonomously extract patterns and trends from historical data, converting raw information into actionable knowledge. This ability provides robust support for decision-making in various domains [16]. In the field of catalysis, machine learning is transforming traditional trial-and-error methods, accelerating catalyst discovery and optimizing reaction conditions [17]. While machine learning holds significant promise for catalyst design, its implementation faces several critical challenges. In particular, the insufficient data quality and quantity significantly impair the accuracy and generalization ability of the models. Additionally, inherent experimental noise and systematic bias adversely affect the accuracy and reliability of the model [18]. Moreover, the complex and multiscale physicochemical phenomena occurring in catalytic systems further complicate the feature selection, especially in identifying key descriptors governing the catalytic performance. Current studies predominantly focus on NH3-SCR within a narrow temperature range (100–400 °C), analyzing only the NO x conversion while ignoring the N2 selectivity. Addressing these limitations requires more comprehensive catalytic datasets as well as advanced machine learning models, capable of dual-target prediction of NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. This study presents a machine learning framework for predicting the performance of SCR catalysts across an extended temperature range (50–650 °C) and rapidly identifying optimal catalyst formulations (Fig. 1 ). A comprehensive database of SCR catalysts was constructed, comprising 751 data points extracted from published papers, with 30 input features categorized into (1) preparation conditions, (2) chemical composition, and (3) reaction parameters. The output features included both NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. CatBoost and LightGBM algorithms were employed for the first time in SCR catalyst research, and exhibited superior capabilities in modeling complex, nonlinear relationships within the dataset. The models identified Mn–Ce–Ti as the optimal catalyst system for NH3-SCR reaction. Feature importance analysis using SHAP values identified key performance-determining factors, whereas heatmap analysis was used to explore interactions between high-impact parameters. To validate the prediction accuracy of the CatBoost model, an external dataset was employed for verification. This approach establishes a robust methodology for data-driven catalyst development and process optimization in SCR systems. 2 Methods 2.1 Database construction and pre-processing A comprehensive database of NH3-SCR catalysts was constructed for machine learning analysis by systematically collecting 751 data points from 73 high-quality publications (2014–2024), which were selected based on three rigorous criteria: (1) complete documentation of catalyst composition, preparation conditions, reaction parameters, and performance metrics; (2) broad coverage of diverse catalyst types and operating conditions; and (3) preference for high-impact journal publications. The above decade was specifically chosen owing to the significant advancements in NH3-SCR technology and improved experimental accuracy achieved during this period. The database comprises 30 input features categorized into 3 performance-critical groups: active component molar ratios, preparation conditions, and reaction conditions, with the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity selected as output features. The frequency distribution of the catalyst constituent elements in the database is shown in Fig. S1. Ce and Mn show the highest occurrence frequencies (385 and 274 instances, respectively), while Si exhibits the lowest frequency (16 instances) among all constituent elements. The commonly used preparation methods (e.g., wet impregnation, coprecipitation, impregnation, and hydrothermal synthesis) and their occurrence frequencies are summarized in Fig. S2; these methods were excluded as quantitative input features owing to their inherent qualitative nature. However, four key preparation parameters (Cal-T, Cal-TM, Dry-T, and Dry-TM) were included as model inputs. The reaction conditions included NOCon, NH3 Con, O2 Con, GHSV, RT, and FR, with their value ranges detailed in Fig. S3. Pearson correlation analysis (Fig. 2 ) revealed no significant inter-feature correlations, which indicates that the features selected for machine learning training are not redundant. To address the significant scale variations among the input features (e.g., calcination temperatures of 200–650 °C and calcination times of 2–6 h), feature normalization was applied to prevent dominance of a particular feature during model training. All features were scaled to [0,1] using min–max normalization (Eq. (1)), which enhances the model convergence and prediction accuracy: (1) y i = x i − x min x max − x min where y i represents the normalized value of the i th instance, x i denotes the original value, and x max/x min correspond to the maximum/minimum values of each feature, respectively. 2.2 Algorithm introduction In this study, the prediction of the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity of SCR catalysts represents a regression problem; hence, 10 machine learning models commonly used in various regression problems were compared: linear regression (LR), ridge, linear SVR, K neighbours regression (KNN), random forest regression (RFR), extra tree regression (ETR), gradient boosting regression (GBR), XGB regression (XGBR), light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM), and categorical boosting (CatBoost). Among them, LightGBM and CatBoost are highly efficient models widely used in fields such as finance and healthcare. They perform exceptionally well when dealing with large amounts of data and complex relationships among characteristic variables. However, they have not yet been used in the field of catalysis. In this study, we first used these models for screening and performance prediction of SCR catalysts. All model training processes were performed using Python 3.9 and the scikit-learn package [19]. The key hyperparameters for each model are listed in Table 1 . The model was partitioned using the train_test_split tool in the scikit-learn package, in which 80 % of the instances in the database were randomly selected as the training set for the model, and the remaining 20 % were used as the test set. Model optimization was performed using 10-fold cross-validation. The latter avoids chance due to a specific division by performing multiple random splits of the dataset, ensuring that the selected hyperparameters and models perform more reliably on unknown data. The training set was randomly divided into 10 equal-sized subsets during the training process, and the subsets did not overlap. In each iteration, one subset was selected as the validation set and the remaining nine subsets were used as the training set; then, 10 model training and validation processes were performed, and the average of the validation results was used as the error of this model. After model optimization, the test set was used to evaluate the performance of the machine learning model. 2.3 Model evaluation To identify the optimal machine learning model for SCR performance prediction, three established evaluation metrics, such as coefficient of determination (R 2), root mean square error (RMSE), and mean absolute error (MAE) were used to assess the model reliability, the prediction accuracy, and the absolute deviation between predicted and actual values, according to Eqs. (2), (3), and (4), respectively: (2) R 2 = 1 − ∑ i = 1 N ( y ai − y i ^ ) 2 ∑ i = 1 N ( y ai − y ‾ ) 2 (3) MAE = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N | y ai − y i ^ | (4) RMSE = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N ( y ai − y i ^ ) 2 where N denotes the total number of observations, y ai represents the experimentally measured NO x conversion or N2 selectivity for the i th sample, y i ^ corresponds to the model-predicted NO x conversion or N2 selectivity value, and y ¯ indicates the mean NO x conversion or N2 selectivity across all samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Model selection Ten regression models were systematically evaluated to identify the best-performing ones for SCR catalyst prediction. As shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 , the linear models (LR, ridge, LSVR) exhibited inferior predictive capability for both NO x conversion and N2 selectivity, with the ridge model showing the poorest performance. For NO x conversion prediction, the ridge achieved training/test R2 of 0.217/0.178, RMSE of 0.252/0.275 and MAE of 0.207/0.228, respectively. Similarly, it yielded the worst training/test R2 of 0.397/0.378, RMSE of 0.106/0.113 and MAE of 0.069/0.073 in N2 selectivity prediction. This poor performance arises from the fundamental limitation of linear models, which applicable to linear feature–target relationships, whereas the SCR catalytic behavior involves complex nonlinear dependencies. The KNN model, whose principle is to predict a target by voting based on its nearest neighbours [20], demonstrated improved predictive performance for both NO x conversion (training/test R 2 = 0.851/0.647; RMSE = 0.110/0.180; MAE = 0.077/0.120) and N2 selectivity (training/test R 2 = 0.995/0.785; RMSE = 0.017/0.067; MAE = 0.012/0.033) compared to the linear models. This enhancement arises from the capacity of the KNN model to capture nonlinear feature relationships, which aligns better with the complex dependencies of the dataset. However, the KNN model remains inferior to ensemble methods owing to its susceptibility to noise, sensitivity to outliers, and reduced effectiveness in high-dimensional feature spaces, making it suboptimal for the present application. The remaining six models (i.e., CatBoost, LightGBM, XGBR, GBR, ETR, and RFR) synergistically combine multiple weak learners to enhance the predictive performance. These algorithms consistently outperformed both the linear and KNN models, exhibiting greater predictive accuracy, enhanced robustness against data variability, and superior generalization capabilities. Among these models, CatBoost demonstrated exceptional performance, achieving near-perfect training accuracy (R 2 = 0.999) while maintaining strong test set predictions for both NO x conversion (R 2 = 0.886, RMSE = 0.103, MAE = 0.073) and N2 selectivity (R 2 = 0.894, RMSE = 0.047, MAE = 0.025). Since its introduction in 2018 [21], CatBoost has emerged as a particularly effective machine learning algorithm for handling complex high-dimensional datasets. The SCR catalyst system targeted in this study presents significant modeling challenges, owing to (1) the high dimensionality of the feature space (30 input features) and (2) the intricate nonlinear relationships between preparation conditions, catalyst composition, and reaction performance. The CatBoost model addresses these challenges through two key innovations: its ordered boosting algorithm, which corrects gradient computation to minimize prediction bias, and advanced regularization techniques that effectively prevent overfitting while enhancing the generalization ability [22]. These technical advantages enabled CatBoost to achieve superior predictive accuracy for both NO x conversion and N2 selectivity (R 2 > 0.88 on test sets), outperforming other ensemble methods. Therefore, CatBoost was selected for detailed feature importance analysis and model interpretation in subsequent tests. 3.2 Feature importance analysis based on SHAP SHAP is a game theory-derived interpretability framework [23], which enables the quantitative evaluation of both global feature importance and local instance-specific contributions in predictive models. In this study, this method was employed to elucidate the decision-making mechanism of the optimized CatBoost model, revealing how the input features collectively govern the predictions of the SCR catalyst performance by quantifying their corresponding contributions. Figs. 5(a)(c) present the mean absolute SHAP values for the input features, quantifying their global importance in the predictions of the CatBoost model; higher values reflect stronger contributions to the prediction of the performance of the SCR catalyst. Additionally, Figs. 5(b)(d) display the distributions of SHAP values, which reveal directional feature effects: positive values denote features that enhance the catalytic activity, while negative values indicate inhibitory factors. This bidirectional interpretation clarifies both the magnitude of the influence of the different features and their mechanistic roles in governing the catalytic behavior. Based on the SHAP analysis, it was found that the RT factor showed the greatest impact on NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. As shown in Figs. 5(a)(c), the mean absolute SHAP values for RT in NO x conversion and N2 selectivity predictions were quantified at 0.137 and 0.036, respectively, revealing its different influence on these performance metrics. As evidenced by the positive SHAP value distribution in Fig. 5 b, elevated temperatures could enhance the NO x conversion, possibly because of (1) the intensified molecular collisions arising from the accelerated thermal motion, which favor the NH3-SCR kinetics [24], and (2) the enhanced redox cycling of the catalyst, improving its adsorption and activation abilities for NH3 and NO species [25]. However, Fig. 5(d) shows that an extremely high temperature (> 400 °C) adversely affected the N2 selectivity, as indicated by negative SHAP values. This is because excessively high temperatures may lead to the non-selective oxidation of NH3 on the catalyst surface, which favors N2O formation over N2 through the reaction 2NH3 + 2O2 → N2O + 3H2O [26]. In addition, high temperatures may also cause the catalyst deactivation by sintering active components and reducing surface area [27]. Moreover, the molar ratio_Mn had a strong influence on NO x conversion and N2 selectivity, with average absolute SHAP values of 0.038 (Fig. 5(a)) and 0.054(Fig. 5(c)), respectively. According to the beeswarm plots of feature importance for NO x conversion (Fig. 5(b)) and N2 selectivity (Fig. 5(d)), molar ratio_Mn showed a positive and negative correlation with the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity, respectively. The former indicates that increasing the molar ratio_Mn enhanced the NO x conversion, while the latter denotes that an excessively high molar ratio_Mn value significantly reduced the N2 selectivity. The first step in the NH3-SCR reaction is generally considered to be the adsorption of NH3. Then, the adsorbed NH3 undergoes a redox reaction with either gaseous NO x (Eley–Rideal mechanism) or adsorbed NO x intermediates (Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism), ultimately producing N2 and H2O [28]. Thus, the acidic sites and reactive oxygen species on the catalyst surface play important roles in reactant adsorption and redox reactions, respectively. The different effects of molar ratio_Mn on the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity arise from the dual role of Mn in modulating the redox capacity and surface acidity of the catalyst. On one hand, the multivalent nature of Mn (Mn²⁺/Mn³⁺/Mn⁴⁺) generates abundant reactive oxygen species on the surface, synergistically and dynamically facilitating redox cycling processes in the catalyst system [29]; on the other hand, the presence of Mn can provide abundant surface acidic sites, facilitating both NH3 adsorption and the subsequent activation, further enhancing the NO x conversion [30]. However, as evidenced by the negative SHAP values in Fig. 5(d), an excessively high molar ratio_Mn adversely affects the N2 selectivity, because it results in an imbalance between redox capacity and surface acidic sites in catalytic systems. This phenomenon causes non-selective NH3 oxidation on catalytic surfaces and reduces the N2 selectivity. As shown in Figs. 5(a)(c), the molar ratio_Ce and molar ratio_Ti emerged as secondary critical factors for both NO x conversion and N2 selectivity, following molar ratio_Mn in influence magnitude. CeO2 serves as a preferred catalytic promoter owing to its unique dual-valent redox cycling (Ce³⁺/Ce⁴⁺), which synergistically enhances the oxygen storage capacity and modulates the surface acidity through oxygen vacancy formation [31]. At the same time, TiO2 serves as an optimal support material, demonstrating exceptional sulfur resistance and thermal stability. It further facilitates the dispersion of active components while creating mesoporous architectures that enhance the acidic site density [32]. Notably, SHAP analysis revealed non-monotonic relationships between the Ce/Ti concentrations and the catalytic performance metrics (Figs. 5(b)(d)), suggesting that their catalytic efficacy originates from synergistic interactions, rather than isolated concentration effects. This phenomenon is likely due to the multicomponent coordination required for effective NH3-SCR mechanisms, where Ce–Ti–Mn ternary interactions (e.g., Ce–O–Ti–Mn–O surface configurations) and preparation parameters (e.g., calcination atmosphere and precursor ratios) collectively govern the reaction pathways [33]. According to Figs. 5(a)(c), the Dry-T and Cal-T were found to have strong effects on the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. However, no clear positive or negative correlation between Dry-T and NO x conversion is observed in Fig. 5(b). This is likely due to synergistic or counteractive interactions between Dry-T and other preparation parameters (e.g., Dry-TM, Cal-TM), resulting in an insignificant individual effect of Dry-T. However, Fig. 5(d) reveals that excessively high Dry-T resulted in a reduced N2 selectivity. This phenomenon may stem from damage to the catalyst pores and reduced specific surface area under excessive Dry-T conditions, which hinder the diffusion of reactants (NO x and NH3) to the active sites and obstruct the NH3 NO reaction pathway for N2 formation [34]. No significant positive or negative correlation was observed between Cal-T and NO x conversion or N2 selectivity (Figs. 5(b)(d)). This is likely due to the presence of other influencing factors in the NH3-SCR process (e.g., RT, GHSV), where SHAP analysis may fail to capture synergistic effects, thereby weakening the contribution of individual features. 3.3 Machine learning-assisted SCR prediction and verification In this section, the pairwise interaction effects of the key input features on the NO x conversion (Fig. 6 ) and N2 selectivity (Fig. 7 ) are systematically investigated using heatmaps based on the CatBoost model. This enables the determination of the optimal operating temperature ranges for the targeted catalyst. This analysis enabled to identify parameter combinations simultaneously achieving > 80 % NO x conversion and N2 selectivity within the 100–300 °C range, including optimized active component ratios (molar ratio_Mn = 0.1–0.3; molar ratio_Ce = 0.1–0.4; molar ratio_Ti = 0.8–0.9) and preparation conditions (Dry-T = 100–120 °C; Cal-T = 400–600 °C). To confirm the accuracy of the CatBoost model in performance prediction and parameter optimization, experimental data from four independent studies [35–38] not included in the original dataset were compared with the model predictions. The selected studies specifically investigated the low-temperature denitrification activity of catalysts with different compositions, with experimental operating conditions detailed in Table 2 . Fig. 8 compares the experimentally measured from literatues and CatBoost-predicted catalytic performance metrics. The model demonstrates predictive consistency across four independent validation studies, with RMSE values ranging from 2.7 % to 19.0 %. This variability aligns with the inherent stochasticity in machine learning training processes, which may induce minor prediction fluctuations between subsequent training iterations. Notably, even with this inherent uncertainty, the CatBoost framework successfully identifies high-performance catalyst formulations within experimentally validated error margins. These findings demonstrate that machine learning can serve as an effective high-throughput screening tool for catalyst development, facilitating the data-driven optimization of synthesis and reaction parameters to accelerate the discovery of high-performance catalytic systems. 4 Conclusion This study establishes a machine learning-driven framework for SCR catalyst screening and performance prediction. A comprehensive catalytic database containing 751 data points with 30 input and 2 output features was systematically constructed from peer-reviewed NH3-SCR studies published between 2014 and 2024. The comparative evaluation of 10 machine learning models showed that the CatBoost model exhibited superior predictive accuracy and generalization ability. SHAP analysis revealed four dominant performance-determining factors: the reaction temperature along with the molar ratios of Mn/Ce/Ti elements, which collectively govern the NO x conversion efficiency and N2 selectivity. Detailed analysis of feature–output thermal maps enabled to identify the optimal parameter ranges ensuring simultaneous achievement of > 85 % NO x conversion and N2 selectivity across the 100–300 °C operational window. The predictive reliability of the model was rigorously validated against independent experimental datasets from the literatures, yielding RMSE values of 2.7 %–19.0 %. The present machine learning approach achieves three critical advancements in catalyst development: (1) systematic optimization of synthesis parameters (metal ratios, thermal processing conditions); (2) reduction in conventional screening costs through predictive modeling; and (3) accelerated discovery of high-efficiency SCR catalysts with tailored temperature–response profiles. coredata.dc:description: Traditional research and development of catalysts mainly rely on experimental trial-and-error methods, which struggle to meet the demand for efficient catalysts in the energy and environmental fields. Applying machine learning to catalyst design can achieve rapid screening of catalysts, thus overcoming the limitations of the traditional trial-and-error methods and solving the problems of low efficiency and high cost affecting catalyst research and development. This paper reports the development of a catalytic database containing 751 sets of data, with 30 input features divided into three categories, such as catalyst composition, preparation conditions, and catalytic reaction conditions, along with NO x conversion and N2 selectivity serving as output features. A machine learning approach was used to assist in the formulation screening and performance prediction of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalysts. The Categorical boosting (CatBoost) model was found to exhibit the best performance among the 10 models explored, with R 2, Mean absolute error (MAE), and Root mean square error (RMSE) values of 0.999, 0.006, and 0.008, respectively. The importance of each input feature for model prediction was obtained using the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) method, which showed that the reaction temperature and Mn elemental molar ratio had the greatest effect on NO x conversion and N2 selectivity. This study provides guidance for the screening, reaction condition optimization, and performance prediction of SCR catalysts. The successful integration of machine learning with experimental methods represents an effective strategy that can accelerate the discovery of catalysts.
